column1: Kwashiorkor is a form of malnutrition that occurs when there is not enough protein in the diet.

Kwashiorkor is most common in areas where there is: - Famine - Limited food supply - Low levels of education (when people do not understand how to eat a proper diet) This disease is more common in very poor countries.
These conditions are responsible for a lack of food, which leads to malnutrition.
Kwashiorkor is very rare in children in the United States.

- Changes in skin pigment - Decreased muscle mass - Diarrhea - Failure to gain weight and grow - Fatigue - Hair changes (change in color or texture) - Increased and more severe infections due to damaged immune system - Irritability - Large belly that sticks out (protrudes) - Lethargy or apathy - Loss of muscle mass - Rash (dermatitis) - Shock (late stage) - Swelling (edema)
Treating kwashiorkor in its late stages will improve the child's general health.
Call your health care provider if your child has symptoms of kwashiorkor.
